title: JavaScript Modules
subject: JavaScript
theory:
Modules allow you to break up your code into separate files.
This makes it easier to maintain the code-base.

Modules rely on the `import` and `export` statements.

examples.output: Browser loads main.js as a module.

common_mistakes.correction: In vanilla JS (browser/Node), you often need the explicit file extension `import ... from './file.js'`.

interview_questions.question: Difference between default and named exports?
interview_questions.answer: Named exports must be imported with braces `{ name }` matching the export name. Default exports can be imported with any name without braces.

practice_problems.problem: Export a function called 'sum' from math.js.

real_world_use_cases.description: Tools like Webpack/Vite bundle all these modules into one file for the browser.

exam_notes: Modules are strict mode by default.
summary: Modules make huge applications manageable by splitting concerns.
